RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Diamond Ethanol, LLC (Diamond)



This RMP resubmission is being submitted to fulfill the 5-year update requirement.



Diamond is an ethanol fuel production plant located in Levelland, Hockley County, Texas.  The plant has completed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for chemicals stored on-site that could exceed reporting thresholds as a requirement of Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.  



ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

Diamond has an ongoing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel on the proper operation and maintenance of plant equipment and preventative maintenance programs. Diamond has emergency response policies in place that are addressed in the facility's SPCC/FRP, and Emergency Action Plan. Most of the listed Plans have a minimum of annual training requirements to keep employees educated on emergency response procedures in place at the facility. New employees are required to read the Plans listed above and undergo training on emergency response procedures prior to initiating responsibilities onsite. Diamond's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release if incidental.  In the event of an emergency, Diamond's employees are not responsible to respond.  The facility will utilize the local fire department as first responders.  In the event of a non-incidental oil release, Diamond has contracted with an off-site spill response contractor to assist first responders with containment and clean-up.



DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

Diamond is located in Levelland, Hockley County, Texas.  The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol

from the natural fermentation of corn. The regulated substances stored at the facility are anhydrous ammonia and a flammable mixture, natural gasoline (denaturant).



WORST CASE AND ALTERNATE CASE SCENARIOS:

Worst Case Scenarios:

1.      Anhydrous Ammonia - Anhydrous ammonia is stored as a gas liquefied by pressure in an aboveground steel tank.  The worst case scenario used is a release of 50% of the storage vessel, creating a toxic vapor cloud.  A determination spreadsheet is included as part of backup documentation onsite detailing the conversion from gallons to pounds of ammonia. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case distance to endpoint, the model results were 4.0 miles radius and are also included as part of the backup documentation maintained onsite. Passive mitigation was not included as part of this scenario. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2010 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information was obtained using Google Earth, DeLorme Topo Software, and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wetland Inventory.  There are several Freshwater Emergent Wetlands located in the endpoint radius for a worst case release of ammonia; however, there are not bodies of water (including creeks and rivers) in the endpoint radius.    



2.    Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The flammable mixture stored onsite is natural gasoline, typically referred to as denaturant.  Natural gasoline is used onsite to denature ethanol prior to shipment off site.   Denaturant is stored in a  steel tank in the facility tank farm. The tank is located within a diked containment structure that contains an impermeable liner with gravel overlay. The facility's denaturant safety data sheet (SDS) was used to determine RMP applicability. The worst case scenario used is the release of the entire contents of the denaturant tank, causing a vapor cloud explosion. RMP Comp was used to determine the worst case distance to endpoint, t

he model results were 0.7 mile radius and are also included as part of the backup documentation maintained onsite.  Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2010 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information was obtained using Google Earth, DeLorme Topo Software, and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wetland Inventory.  There are three (3) Freshwater Emergent Wetlands located in the endpoint radius for a worst case release of denaturant; however, there are not bodies of water (including creeks and rivers) in the endpoint radius. 

   

Alternate Scenarios:

1.      Anhydrous Ammonia: The alternate scenario used for anhydrous ammonia is a release due to a rupture disk/relief valve failure from the ammonia piping system. This scenario is considered the most likely cause of an ammonia release onsite. The alternate release duration assumed is 30 minutes with an atmospheric stability of D and wind speed of 3.0 m/sec. The facility control room is manned 24 hours/day and would be alerted of the relief valve failure at the ammonia tank within minutes.  RMP Comp was used to determine the alternate distance to endpoint, the model results were 0.4 mile radius and are part of the backup documentation maintained onsite. Population data was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2010 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information was obtained using Google Earth, DeLorme Topo Software, and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wetland Inventory. No environmental receptors are affected by an alternate case release of ammonia.  



2.      Flammable Mixture (Denaturant): The alternate scenario used for the flammable mixture is the release of natural gasoline due to a tanker truck loadout spill, causing a vapor cloud fire.  The endpoint used was an over pressurization of 1 PSI, a worst case option. Denaturant deliveries at the facility typically occur during normal business hour

s with a facility staff member overseeing loadout operations - therefore a release at the loadout area could be ceased within minutes by manual overrides.  The loadout area also has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment of the tank farm.  For this scenario passive and active mitigation was not considered, as the mitigation strategies currently in place would not contain a vapor cloud fire. RMP Comp was used to determine the alternate distance to endpoint, the model results were <0.1 mile radius and are part of the backup documentation maintained onsite. Population data was based on the minimum mile radius (0.3 miles) and was obtained using Circular Area Profiling Software (CAPS) which incorporates 2010 U.S. Census Data. Public receptor information was obtained using Google Earth, DeLorme Topo Software, and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's National Wetland Inventory. No environmental receptors are affected by an alternate case release of denaturant.



GENERAL ACCIDENTIAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

Diamond has developed a Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) Plan with the purpose of identifying the most likely spill locations at the facility and implementing strategies to prevent a spill.  This plan is prepared by a professional engineer and requires the facility to complete routine inspections and maintenance on oil containing equipment.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

There have been no accidents in the covered areas since the establishment of Diamond.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

Diamond has several safety programs in place at the facility that incorporate emergency response, including an Emergency Action Plan, Health and Safety Plan, Facility Response Plan, and Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures Plan.

The facility also conducts employee training as part of facility activities.  Diamond's corporate policy places the utmost importance on worker, public and environ

mental safety, which is reflected in facility plans and training activities.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

Diamond routinely reviews incidents and accidents to improve safety including equipment testing and safety assessments.  The facility has and will continue to coordinate response activities with emergency responders including drills and deployment exercises.  Safety improvements are an on-going process at the facility.
